 With the current system we use:
 
 For firearms recovered in crimes, we trace them by contacting the manufacturer, who then tells us when and where the gun was shipped for sale. The FFL dealer is required to keep all records of his sales, and the purchaser's name is recovered from those forms. BATFE does all this background research for local LE, and it sends the local agency a printout with the date of sale-name, address, etc. of dealer-and the name, address etc. of the purchaser. The purchaser can then be contacted so we can find out from him what happened to the gun. Traces very rarely help solve crimes because they almost never assist us in proving who brandished or fired the gun at the crime scene. The trace records are helpful if the gun is newly bought (say less than one year ago), and the original purchaser is already the suspect (and it gets better if he has also already denied any connection to the gun in the first place).
